Authors:
Amy M Grooters, C. A. Levesque, Tara L Rintoul, Scott A.
Redhead, Sally Glockling, Chi-Yu Chen, Arthur W.A.M. de Cock, Chris
Frederik Jakobus Spies
Title:
Molecular phylogeny and taxonomy of Lagenidium-like oomycetes
pathogenic to mamma ls
Keywords:
Oomycetes, phylogeny, Paralagenidium, Myzocytiopsis,
Salilagenidium, Chlamydomyzium
Abstract:
Over the past twenty years, infections caused by
previously unrecognised oomycete pathogens with morphological and
molecular similarities to known Lagenidium species have been observed
with increasing frequency, primarily in dogs but also in cats and
humans. Recently, three of these pathogens were formally described as L.
giganteum forma caninum, L. deciduum, and Paralagenidium karlingii
without phylogenetic verification. In light of the complex nature of
Lagenidium taxonomy and the recent reports of mammalian pathogenic
species of Lagenidium by Vilela et al. (2015), the status of these taxa
needed to be verified with due consideration of the available data for
Lagenidium and its allied genera (Dick 1997, 2001). This study does so
through morphologic characterisation of the mammalian pathogenic
species, and phylogenetic analyses of SSU, ITS, LSU, TUBB, COX1 and
COX2sequences representing a wide range of oomycetes, including at least
five genera with species once considered to be Lagenidium. The six-gene
phylogeny generally supports the classification of Lagenidium by Dick
(1997, 2001) with a well-supported Lagenidium clade that includes the
mammalian pathogens L. giganteum f. caninum and L. deciduum, and
well-supported clades for Myzocytiopsis and Salilagenidium. The genus
Paralagenidium is phylogenetically unrelated to any of the main clades
within the class Peronosporomycetes. This genus contains two species:
Pl. karlingii, and an undescribed species referred to as Pl. sp.
AG-2015a. Phylogenetic data supports the inclusion of some novel
mammalian pathogenic species reported by Vilela et al. (2015) in L.
deciduum, Pl. karlingii, and Pl. sp. AG-2015a. Close relationships
between pathogens of mammals and those of insects/nematodes were
revealed. Further characterisation of lagenidiaceous taxa is needed to
establish the risk of mammalian infection by pathogens of insects and
nematodes.
